start.speaker: Pixel
start.text: Level 3 - Time to give your code a BRAIN! ðŸ§  We're learning how to make decisions!
start.followUp: You know how games react to what you do? That's what we're building today!

options.text: Yes! Let's make smart code!
Wait, like the choices in games?

gameAnalogy.speaker: Pixel
gameAnalogy.text: Exactly! Like when your health hits zero and it's game over, or when you find a key and suddenly doors open!
gameAnalogy.followUp: Every single game moment is an IF-THEN decision. Ready to code your own?

options.text: This is gonna be cool!

ifStatement.speaker: Pixel
ifStatement.text: So here's the magic word: 'if'! It's like asking Python a question and doing something based on the answer!
ifStatement.codeExample:
player_health = 25

if player_health < 30:
    print('Warning: Low health!')
    print('Find a health potion!')
ifStatement.followUp: Notice how the code after 'if' is pushed to the right? That's how Python knows what to do when it's true!

options.text: But what happens when health is fine?
Why's the code all pushed over like that?

explainIndent.speaker: Pixel
explainIndent.text: Oh that's actually super important! The spaces show Python what's inside the 'if' and what's not!
explainIndent.codeExample:
if player_has_key:
    print('Opening door...')  # Inside the if
    print('You enter the room!')  # Also inside!
print('Game continues...')  # Outside - always runs!
explainIndent.followUp: It's like... imagine the indented stuff is in a special box that only opens when the condition is true!

options.text: Got it! So what about when it's false?

elseStatement.speaker: Pixel
elseStatement.text: That's where 'else' comes in! It's the backup plan when your 'if' condition isn't true!
elseStatement.codeExample:
coins = 45
item_cost = 50

if coins >= item_cost:
    print('Purchase successful!')
    coins = coins - item_cost
else:
    print('Not enough coins!')
    print('You need', item_cost - coins, 'more coins')
elseStatement.followUp: See? If you CAN afford it, buy it! Otherwise, tell them they're broke! Simple!

options.text: What if I need like... five different options?
Ooh, I wanna try this!

elifStatement.speaker: Pixel
elifStatement.text: Boom! That's where 'elif' saves the day! It's short for 'else if' - perfect for multiple paths!
elifStatement.followUp: It checks from top to bottom and stops at the FIRST match - like falling through platforms until you hit one!

options.text: Wait, what if two could be true?
I need to see more of this!

multipleTrue.speaker: Pixel
multipleTrue.text: Great question! Only the FIRST match wins! Once Python finds a true condition, it's done checking!
multipleTrue.codeExample:
age = 15

if age >= 10:  # True! Stop here!
    print('You can play rated E10+ games')
elif age >= 13:  # Also true, but we never check!
    print('You can play Teen games')
elif age >= 17:  # Never even looked at
    print('You can play Mature games')
multipleTrue.followUp: Want to check ALL conditions? Then you need separate 'if' statements instead!

options.text: Yeah, show me how that works!

separateIfs.speaker: Pixel
separateIfs.text: Check this out - separate 'if's are like multiple checkpoints - you can trigger them ALL!
separateIfs.followUp: Perfect for when you can have multiple power-ups at once, right?

options.text: Can I check two things in one if?

tryCondition.speaker: Pixel
tryCondition.text: Time to code a battle! Here's the setup...
tryCondition.followUp: Your enemy has 50 HP, you hit for 30 damage. What should we check?

options.text: Can I one-shot them?
Is it a boss fight?

trySuccess.speaker: Pixel
trySuccess.text: Smart! Always check for the instant win first!
trySuccess.codeExample:
enemy_hp = 50
attack_power = 30

if enemy_hp <= attack_power:
    print('One-shot victory!')
else:
    hits_needed = enemy_hp // attack_power + 1
    print(f'Need {hits_needed} hits to win!')
trySuccess.followUp: See? Your code just calculated combat outcomes! Ready for something even cooler?

options.text: Hit me with the cool stuff!

tryLogic.speaker: Pixel
tryLogic.text: Hmm, but the enemy only has 50 HP - that condition would never happen!
tryLogic.followUp: Gotta match your conditions to your actual values! Ready for the next level?

options.text: Yeah, I see what went wrong!

moreExamples.speaker: Pixel
moreExamples.text: Check out this game menu - it's all conditionals!
moreExamples.followUp: Every menu in every game works like this! But what if we need to check TWO things?

options.text: Yeah! Like having a key AND being level 10?

logicalOperators.speaker: Pixel
logicalOperators.text: YES! That's exactly it! We use 'and', 'or', and 'not' - they're like logic glue!
logicalOperators.codeExample:
# AND - both gotta be true
has_key = True
door_unlocked = False

if has_key and not door_unlocked:
    print('Use key to unlock door!')

# OR - just need one
health = 15
has_potion = True

if health < 20 or has_potion:
    print('Healing available!')
logicalOperators.followUp: 'and' = both, 'or' = either one, 'not' = opposite. It's that simple!

options.text: Show me something really complex!
Can I put ifs inside other ifs?

complexConditions.speaker: Pixel
complexConditions.text: Alright, let's go all out - here's a real combat AI!
complexConditions.followUp: That's actual game AI logic right there! See the ifs inside ifs?

options.text: Whoa, ifs inside ifs! Tell me more!

nestedIfs.speaker: Pixel
nestedIfs.text: Exactly! You can put ifs inside ifs - like opening a door to find another door!
nestedIfs.followUp: The inside if only happens if the outside if is true first. Like unlocking levels in a game!

options.text: I'm ready for the final challenge!

finalChallenge.speaker: Pixel
finalChallenge.text: BOSS CHALLENGE TIME! Let's build a treasure chest system!
finalChallenge.followUp: Here's the deal: You need a key OR lockpicks to open it. High level players always get rare loot!

options.text: I understand conditionals now!
